He knows the authorship because he accepts that it is R. G. Hawkins.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is his name which is there.

—Senator Chaney cannot have it both ways. Senator Chaney has said: `Look, we are upset that you have condemned Hawkins in the way you have. Hawkins is the man who did it and we accept that he is obviously the author of the document.' Senator Chaney is talking about the briefing note; he has not gone beyond that, to the research papers that might have existed. He has just asked for the authorship of the briefing note, the sources and the advice. If he wants to amend his motion, he may go ahead and do that but if he is going to leave it as it is that is really what it amounts to. It seems extraordinary that we should send off to a particular committee a document in respect of which the Opposition wants to carry out an exercise which really would be better carried out in the star chamber, because what it really wants is to have people cross-examined very closely about this particular document and about what is behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: How can it be that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is any better placed than any other committee to go into what is in effect an examination of this document of almost star chamber proportions? Should not the motion say that we should send it off to a body of cross-examiners comprising, for example, Senator Alston and Senator Puplick? I was almost going to say Senator Newman, but she has such grace that she would not be vicious enough to cross-examine--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being sexist, like Evans. Be careful.

—No, I am not being sexist; I am simply talking in terms of her nature as I know it. People talk about the Westminster system, but this seems to be an extraordinary exercise. What is the Westminster system? Certainly star chambers have not been around since the Westminster system has been in existence.

SPEECH.PARA: Finding out exactly what the Opposition wants to do is very difficult. It seems to want to have a debate on economic policy, and it says that that is urgent. Of course it is urgent but we have a debate on economic policy every day. The Opposition wants to discover evidence with which it can embarrass the Government. Perhaps that is a perfectly legitimate exercise, but is it a matter of urgency? Does it want to hold up the whole parliamentary process so it can go on a fishing expedition, so it can get some evidence with which it can embarrass various Ministers in Question Time? Certainly it might want to embarrass the Government and Ministers in Question Time-that is quite proper-but is it proper to hold up the business of the chamber so that it can go on a fishing expedition?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is General Business time.

—That is right, but it is an exercise in fishing because the Opposition wants to get material that it can put to this side to embarrass it in some way. `Look', the Opposition will say, `You say that; didn't Mr Smith say this and didn't your research paper say that?'. If the Opposition wants to go into an exercise of interrogation or discovery, it should do so through the various channels open to it. I am not telling members of the Opposition how to run their business but I would have thought the proper use of Question Time would be the way to do that. They can ask questions then and use the material they get from that in debate. They can go to their own sources if they like, their own economists, and get this material that they want, but why do they want to hold up Parliament? This is what I want to hear from Opposition speakers. They are doing it so they can get evidence that they can then introduce into a debate on the economic state of the country. This is not a debate about the economy; it ought to be a debate about the sources on which the Government relies for its economic statements.
—That is what we asked for-the sources.

—Of course Senator Chaney wants the sources, but he wants to obtain them by way of a particular exercise. He wants to go on a fishing expedition. The logic of his position is this: Each side of the chamber merely exchanges all the material it has on economic matters and we go through it all and debate it that way. That might well be an exercise that he wants to go through, but I cannot quite understand why he wants to suspend Standing Orders to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a matter of suspending Standing Orders to debate the economy, to debate whether housing interest rates ought to be 13.5 per cent or something else, to debate whether the current account is too great or to talk about prices or wages. It is not a matter of suspending Standing Orders to debate any of those things. None of those things would be the subject of a debate which would follow the suspension of Standing Orders to determine whether this matter ought to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Finance and Government Operations Committee is a creature of this Senate. I would have thought that it would be almost a dereliction of our duty to send these sorts of things off to that Committee when economic policy is the sort of thing that we ought to debate in this chamber. As to the evidence that Senator Chaney wants, he wants to go on a fishing expedition to get it.

He said that it is an urgent matter but he does not want the Committee to report back until 26 March. If the examination of this document is so urgent, why is it that, in the terms of his own motion, he does not want the Committee to report back before 26 March? It seems to me to be a quite extraordinary exercise to go through to call for the suspension of the consideration of the business of this House so that he can get some sort of fishing expedition going to bring something back here by 26 March.

Would he want an extension of that time if he did not get the sort of material that he wanted? Would he want it to go off to some other committee if this Committee's report was not satisfactory? It seems to be a most extraordinary exercise. For example, it has not been explained why he wants it to go to the Finance and Government Operations Committee rather than to some other committee. I suppose another committee it could go to is the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. There are some lawyers on that Committee who might be able to cross-examine witnesses for him.

The more one looks at the whole thing, the more it becomes a quite irrelevant proposition to suspend Standing Orders to take up this motion. It seems to me that the motion is quite misdirected. It tries to send off to the Finance and Government Operations Committee an exercise which should be conducted in this chamber through Question Time or in debate and which should not be hidden away amongst the few honourable senators who constitute the particular committee referred to, namely, the Finance and Government Operations Committee. On the other hand, the moving of the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders can lead to the very healthy political debate that has taken place. That may well have been the reason why Senator Chaney introduced this motion-simply to get a debate going and simply to make a political point. I think that a political point has been made, and made very well; but I think that should be the end of it.

If there is something more to it than trying to make political capital out of it-political debate is what this is all about and political debate is very important-it certainly has not come out in the sorts of suggestions that have been made on the other side. It has been alleged that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tried to get Senator Ryan to change her stance. That is not a matter that should be sent off to a committee; it is a matter that should be brought out here. There has been debate about whether a public servant has been insulted. If he has been insulted, that point ought to be made in this chamber in the public arena, not before some hidden away committee.

The more one goes through the various points that have been raised in the debate, the more it becomes apparent that the sorts of things that have been raised ought to be raised in the House in the course of the various debates that take place again and again on the economy. It could be debated as a matter of public importance on a day set aside for that to take place. That is an instrument that can be used by the Leader of the Opposition to make any point that he wants to make. But how this matter can be said to be urgent is quite difficult to follow.

Senator Sir John Carrick said that the Minister is in the hot seat. If she is, should that lead to the suspension of Standing Orders so that this matter can be debated? I hardly think so. It is simply a matter of making that point. Senator Sir John Carrick said quite correctly that the Minister could have claimed privilege on this. She did not do that. She was praised for that and in being praised it was not denied that the authorship of the document is as it appears. The document speaks very much for itself and nobody seems to have suggested for one minute that it does not. It has been said that it is significant to find out whether what is in the document is the Minister's view. She can be asked in Question Time: `Is that still your view?' The Leader of the Opposition could get his friends in the other place to ask the Treasurer (Mr Keating) whether that is his view. It is very difficult to see why this is urgent.

It is said that the question of the economy is an enormous question. Of course it is an enormous question. That is why we debate it in this chamber again and again. I would be very interested to learn from the very eloquent speakers who will follow why the subject of this motion-its terms were written by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, quite advisedly I take it-should be a matter of urgency. The question of the economy can be debated at any time, so how can this be urgent? The Leader of the Opposition wants to go on a fishing expedition in the hope that he will find out all sorts of other things which he might be able to use in Question Time or to debate an MPI. If he wants some sort of policing committee formed to investigate the material that both sides of the House have, so be it; but that is very dangerous. We might get to the stage where the committee has to get the rack out to make sure that a person examined before the committee is telling the truth. It is a matter of the examination of witnesses in a situation of awe. If the committee wanted to take the awe a bit further, it could get round to the rack as well to make sure that it got to the truth of the matter. That seems to be very much what this sort of motion would lead to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders moved by Senator Chaney. I do not wish to reiterate many of the points that have been made by both sides of the chamber but perhaps I could be of assistance to Senator Cooney by explaining to him that the interest of the Senate in this document is that it is the property of the Senate. It was tabled in the Senate, but it was repudiated by the Government that tabled it. Therefore, we have a motion before the Senate to determine the status of that document, the authorship of it and the sources of advice which is quoted in that document.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I wanted to speak earlier in the debate was to point out that there seems to be some confusion in the minds of all those who have spoken for the Government about the brief that was prepared and tabled today with regard to Government policy and the document that was tabled yesterday. It is said in the `talking points' to the answer to the question today that was tabled:
Document tabled in the Senate was not an accurate statement of government policy.

It seems to me that there is great confusion in the minds of those who are putting forward this information as to the difference between Government policy and the outcomes of Government policy. That is why there is the interest of the Senate in this particular document. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), before tabling it yesterday, read from the earlier part of the document that the Government's policy and economic strategy `is directed at providing an environment conducive to achieving lower interest rates'. This document, which was written by the public servant concerned, quoted within it:

The Report of the Indicative Planning Council to be presented to the March 1987 meeting of the Australian Housing Council will contain an assumption that any reductions in market rates that occur this year will not be sufficient to allow reductions in housing loan interest rates in 1987.

That is not in any way in conflict with government policy, which of course is seeking lower interest rates, but it is pointing out that government policy is not going to achieve lower interest rates. So the Government is disclaiming the document that was tabled yesterday, and may be reasserting that its policy, particularly in an election year, is to achieve, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, prospects for falls in the general level of interest rates in 1987. That might be the policy, but we have, as the property of the Senate, a document that says that will not be the outcome. That is the interest of putting that before a Senate committee, to determine the way in which those matters, that will be put by the Indicative Planning Council before the State Ministers in March, were achieved and the basis of that information.

It is said by the Government that this was written prior to the Government's announcement of a mini-Budget in May. I can only suggest that the statements of Senator Evans today foreshadow that there must be very substantial changes of direction in this statement that is to be produced in May by the Government, if it is to uphold its policy and to allow the Prime Minister to continue to say that there will be falls in interest rates in 1987. The advice of the Indicative Planning Council-I think we have today traversed the number of committees that this public servant sits on and works with-shows that this is not the outcome that will be achieved. I feel that when the Government says that that which was tabled yesterday was in error, it is confusing what might be its own policy objective and what will be the outcome from the best advice that can be given by those who are planning housing during the forthcoming year.

It was said somewhere, I think by one of my colleagues, that the learned doctor has given advice to the Indicative Planning Council. I would rather put it that he receives advice from the Council, because those who sit on that Council represent the industry; they represent all sorts of people in the community who are involved in the provision of housing, in the financing of housing and all of those matters. So it is not the personal view of a particular public servant that was put in the Senate yesterday and which has now become a document of the Senate, it is the advice of the Indicative Planning Council that will go before the Government.

Whilst the Government might find it uncomfortable to have advice in a document or a report of that kind that obviously will come forward in March, governments have to live with that. In a matter as important as housing policy and interest rate policy I think the Government ought to be prepared to subject itself to an examination of the way in which the Council came to that view: That although the Government might have that policy to reduce interest rates this year, that will not be achieved. So I think our interest in the status of the document does raise that difference between what might be a government policy and what might be the outcome of it.

I do not want to make any comment at all about the reputations of public servants or about any of the matters that, during yesterday and today, have been matters of public comment. I do not think that is the point. I think the point of it is that the Government really cannot manage the news by saying that what was put down yesterday as an authoritative comment by an indicative planning council on housing is not government policy and therefore is in error. That is just managing the news, and it is probably the worst time of all to start managing the news when there are such grave matters of concern about the economy. So it would not hurt if expert advice were different from what the Government's objectives might be. But I think it would be fair enough for the Senate, now that the document is its property, to examine it to see what the basis of that advice was and how that can assist us to understand the concern that there is in the Australian community about housing matters.

As I understand it, from public report, that was a matter that was also expressed in the Government Caucus this week. The Government Caucus itself, being interested in the matter of housing, took a recommendation that I assume it will work upon, and that is to retain the interest rate ceiling for those existing loans. I wonder what advice was given to Caucus about the likely outcome of interest rates this year to lead Caucus, as I read it, unanimously to decide that that ceiling ought to remain. Was it that the Government or the Prime Minister was able to say to it: `Don't worry about it. Housing rates are going to fall this year'? Or was it that Caucus had a proper review of the seriousness of the situation and the many economic indicators that really do make it almost impossible to suggest that there will be a fall in interest rates in this forthcoming year?

I know there are other speakers, but I rose simply to make those two points: Firstly, to explain to Senator Cooney that it is not unusual for the Senate to determine the status, the accuracy or the content of a document that comes within its own purview and which has been tabled in the Senate. Our particular interest in this document is that it was tabled and then disclaimed as being in error. So there is a special interest in that document and not just as a document that could be tabled at any other Question Time. The second matter that I think is of interest is that there has been this confusion through all the public statements of government policy and what I believe ought to be addressed, and that is, the outcome of government policy and the likelihood that government policy will be achieved in this election year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am moved to think what a difference a few years makes, because I have listened today to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle telling us how much extra information she would like and how enthusiastic she is for this extra information to come to light. It was only five years ago that I served on Estimates Committee C, on which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was a very gracious Minister who used to give us information provided we badgered her for something like 30 hours. I instance, of course, the 1982 post-Budget survey. The one we first asked questions about did not exist and it gradually emerged that it may have existed. I think at the ninth meeting of Estimates Committee C it miraculously appeared. So it seems to me that we have a slight conversion here. That is an understandable conversion, from being a Minister to being in the Opposition. Maybe I have had a conversion the other way, I am not sure. But I at least now acknowledge the enthusiasm with which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle seeks information. It only goes to prove that the longer we are in politics, the more we learn.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the second such motion in two days. It is a pity that I threw away my very brief notes from yesterday as I could have just regurgitated them. Yesterday we heard that it was of utmost urgency to suspend Standing Orders so that we could refer something to a committee. On that occasion the Liberal Party was not quite so susceptible to democratic principles or anything else and threw it out, and I think with good reason. I do not say that the Opposition is acting cynically. Today it has suddenly come in with a renewed burst of enthusiasm, but unfortunately in the meantime the Australian Democrats have lost theirs, so apparently we are not going to get a reference to either committee. We on the Government side at least have the consistency of a stone wall. We have opposed the references of both to a committee.

I said yesterday and I say again: It is a legitimate political tactic of the Opposition or the Democrats, when a sensitive issue comes up, to have it referred to a committee-totally legitimate of course. It is not legitimate for the Government of this chamber if that succeeds on every occasion, because senators will not be able to deal with all those sorts of references. There are many references before existing committees that we simply do not deal with. I am sure we have all had experience of this Parliament saying to the members of this or that committee that there are about six or seven items to be dealt with. We cannot deal with them all at the one time and it is very difficult then to set priorities. What will happen if this is referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations? It has many existing inquiries-unless it has dramatically changed in the last few years-and which one does it give priority to?

The fact that the Government or the casting vote of the Chairman has priority puts the committee in the position of having to ask: Does it shuffle it down to the bottom of its references or does it give it priority? How is that determined-just by a democratic vote or consensus? Usually, I would add, consensus has a lot to do with this on those committees, but as Senator Coates noted before, if something is referred to a Senate committee the normal courtesy is to see the chairman and to ask as to his or her timetable to see whether he or she can fit the reference in. That was not done on this occasion.

One has to ask why this is so urgent. The Opposition has a little merit in saying that it is urgent. The only alternative for the Opposition, other than to refer it to a committee, is to let it go on the Notice Paper, let it come up under General Business in the Senate and have it put through. Why is that not a particularly attractive course? I can tell honourable senators why. It is because the Senate is anarchy personified. It has no discipline. It has no control over its business. What we do in this chamber, and what we have done in the last two weeks, is to waste an interminable amount of time on all sorts of issues so that the Government will be left in the situation in early June of being accused of trying to rush legislation through, with all of the inhibitions that that brings on the rights of back benchers and the Opposition. We have had one Bill go through in two weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four today.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have had news of a late swing, so I must acknowledge that we got some through today. It has to be acknowledged that, if this subject came up under General Business for 2 1/2 hours, it would probably be talked out and never acted upon unless the Opposition wanted to bring it up repeatedly. That is not a condemnation of us on the Government side; it is a condemnation of the aimless way in which this chamber meanders under the guise of all sorts of democratic rights. In the end we become the victims of a tyranny of filibuster. We become the victims of mindless speeches and delaying and frustrating tactics. If this does not go through today, the Opposition will be the victim of part of the system that we have all helped to create. I suppose that is why there is at least some validity in this, as the only way these days to get a reference to a committee is to suspend Standing Orders and go through an urgency debate. What then evolves, I suppose with the compliance of us all, is that we have a debate to try to suspend Standing Orders. That never actually happens. What I am trying to argue is that we debate the subject then and try to embarrass the Presiding Officers of this chamber by wandering off into the distance and debating the substantive issue. The substantive issues in this case have been well and truly canvassed here this afternoon. Out of respect for you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will not do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the issue of ministerial briefs. We really have a couple of choices here. They do not exist only to support Ministers. They are also available so that, when one asks a question without notice-especially in this chamber, where the Ministers represent 21 other Ministers-one can get some sort of an answer. That is why they exist. If Opposition senators want to do away with that system, they are welcome to do so. That would turn Question Time into an even more sterile event than it is at the moment. Question Time is supposed to be an innovative and combative time when information flows out, where the Opposition can impress and where Ministers can impress. But what do we have in this chamber? We have a rather convoluted Question Time. If the Opposition wants to stop Ministers using briefs, or wants to hold Ministers to absolutely everything contained in a ministerial brief, we will have an even more sterile Question Time. We might as well not have it. We might as well go to a 20-minute Question Time because we would not get any information at all. Whilst Ministers may often stonewall on some policy issues, I am very impressed by their eagerness-sometimes I am almost depressed by their eagerness-to try to answer seriously the silly questions that come from opposite.

I want to mention a couple of other points. Senator Sir John Carrick, in his usual style, went on about the Westminster system, never accurately defining what it is. We have an implied theory of what it is to suit the particular circumstances. But, if we look back to the reality of the previous Liberal Government, we see that none of the criteria that he put forward today ever applied to any of its Ministers. Of course, on many occasions he used ministerial briefs, except, I suppose, when he was talking about cosmic mix and related matters. But, on the whole, he tended to use ministerial briefs when he was a Minister. He also knows and realises very strongly that everything in a ministerial brief is not always included in an answer to the Senate; that is, a whole variety of information appears in a ministerial brief and the Minister uses part of it to respond to a particular question. It is not absolute Government policy that is contained in those briefs; it never could be and never should be. There is no way that everything that appears in a brief will be the view of the Minister or of the Minister representing a Minister.

We saw last night an example of the Public Service at work. A Senate committee sat until 2 a.m. investigating equalisation. In the row of witnesses, the Department of Communications was at one end and Telecom Australia at the other; Senator Giles will confirm this. They did not put forward exactly one common view and one common truth. They put to our committee their view of the truth and their judgment. It is then up to us to make a judgment as to who is correct. We do not expect one single view to come from the Government. After all, this is not the Soviet Union. Public servants' views are very valued, but in the end it is the Minister who makes policy. It is the Government that expresses policy-not a ministerial brief, on which many public servants work very hard and very effectively in the service of this chamber or the other chamber to assist the Government.

This is really a bit of a storm in a teacup. If this motion is not carried today, that will not block off all opportunity to raise the issue again. There are many ways that one can raise this issue. As, I think, Senator Cooney indicated, it can be raised by way of an urgency motion or a matter of public importance. Also, the Opposition could try to go through the due process of bringing it up on a General Business day and asking for a bit of discipline so that it comes to a vote. The Opposition could do that, but it never does. Opposition senators, instead of waffling on for half an hour, could cut their speeches down and ask, through the Whip system, that this matter be brought to a vote and referred to a committee in the appropriate way. If that fails, they still have the Estimates committees that will be meeting probably in April or May and in which this matter can be pursued even further. I encourage that-primarily because I am not a member of the Estimates committee that would deal with this area.

I summarise by saying that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) came in here today and admitted that she made an error on one or two points. I think that is very commendable. That is in the Westminster tradition. I do not think anyone here seriously suggests that that constitutes such an error as to imperil her ministerial future. It clearly does not do that. From time to time Ministers are error prone. Have honourable senators ever asked themselves why? Have they looked at the hours that they work? Very often one does not think of these things when in opposition. When we sat on that side I am sure that we did not give much credence to the hours put in by Ministers, especially when we called quorums when special meetings were being held with the then Prime Minister in 1982 to consider whether to have a special election. I am sure we all remember that. The then Government members and senators kept rushing over from the oval office backwards and forwards. I do not know whether Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was one of those. But there is a lot of pressure on Ministers and they do make occasional errors. On the scale of things, this is an extremely minor error.

Let us say that this was to be sent to a committee. What would the Opposition senators intend to do at that committee? Do they seriously suggest, as I thought Senator Chaney implied, that members of that committee would make an assessment of where interest rates will go in the next 12 months? Perhaps we could ask them to tip the Melbourne Cup winner at the same time. We may as well do that because it would involve one person's judgment. That is what stock markets, et cetera, are about. The best thing that a government can do is to indicate the direction in which it thinks interest rates should be going and the direction in which economic indicators point towards them going. That is all that a government can do. It cannot guarantee them.

We all remember the classic example of a Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Anthony, who said that he would eat his hat if interest rates did not go down by 2 per cent in the next year. We all know, of course, that they went up. None of us saw him eat his hat. Where was Senator Sir John Carrick's Westminster tradition? I demanded that Doug Anthony eat a hat some time. But he never has. Predicting the level of interest rates is a foolish thing to do. Very few Government Ministers predict the level that interest rates will reach. By the way, they are willing to predict the trend, and so they should. But they do not actually predict the level to which interest rates will go.

What the Opposition really wanted-why do Opposition senators not admit this?-was this issue debated in General Business time. It had no other device, so it moved this motion to try to debate it now. But do any Opposition senators realistically think that anything productive will come out of a reference to a committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us try.
—Senator Alston may like to try. But I bet the Opposition gets nowhere if it goes there. It will get absolutely nowhere. It will be a waste of time.
—Let us try it.

—Senator Walters whines on: `Let us try'. She was not saying `Let us try' yesterday. Where was the democrat or the libertine in Senator Walters who wanted an inquiry then? She voted against it, or is her name not in the division record? Let us not go on with the sanctimoniousness of all this. It is a legitimate tactic for an opposition to do this but let us cut out the pompousness and the sanctimoniousness of this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, we have been consistent in not having every item referred to a committee. Government does not run by every item being referred to committees; it comes out of decisions in this chamber. The sooner this chamber is willing to make more mature decisions and organise its procedures to achieve those decisions the better. I finish with this warning: If the Opposition does not do it now and it happens to come into government it should not come pleading to us to help it out. This chamber can be made into a chamber of anarchy-I suspect at times bordering on nihilism-by an opposition that wants to bog down a government. All right, that is the Opposition's tactic, but it is a tactic that always boomerangs, as we probably find now it has boomeranged on us because of our tactics, at least from 1981 to 1983 when I was here. We should change the procedures in this chamber so that we can bring issues such as this to a sensible vote instead of going through all the charade of an urgency motion, canvassing the issues when we should not be canvassing issues, putting it to a vote and failing at that point. If we had the proper procedures in this chamber it would be far less likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am pleased to inform the Senate that at this morning's meeting of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills I was elected to chair the Committee in succession to Senator Tate. On behalf of the Committee I should like to take this opportunity to place on record the Committee's appreciation of the valuable service rendered by Senator Tate as the foundation Deputy Chairman of the Committee and its Chairman between 1983 and 1986. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

In that role I wish to draw the attention of the Senate particularly to the comments of the Committee on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986 in the report which I have just presented. Two clauses of that Bill make changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which are retrospective to the dates on which the respective proposals to make those changes to the law were announced. In neither case was the announcement made to the Parliament but presumably by way of a Press conference or Press release.

The Committee has stated in the past that it recognises the special conventions associated with the backdating of certain changes to the taxation laws to the date of the announcement of the proposal to make the relevant change, for example in the Budget statement. However the Committee has repeatedly drawn attention to cases where changes to the taxation laws have been made retrospective to the date of some ministerial announcement, not made to the Parliament, but made by way of a Press release or a Press statement.

So far as the Committee has been able to ascertain, this practice of announcing a prospective change to the law to the Press with the promise that the subsequent legislation will be retrospective to the date of the announcement was first used in 1974 by the then Treasurer, Mr Crean. On that occasion the legislation to implement the proposal was not in fact introduced before the change of government in November 1975. At the time the justification advanced for the making of such retrospective legislation was the need to close loopholes in the taxation law, a justification which was also used for such legislation by Mr Lynch and Mr Howard as Treasurers under the previous Government. However from the time when the Committee first noted this practice in its First Report of 1984 in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983 it has become increasingly prevalent to the point where it now seems to be the almost invariable practice of the Taxation Office to announce changes to the law in this way with the promise of retrospective legislation introduced many months after the original announcement.

In the past year the Committee drew attention to examples of such `legislation by Press release' in its Eighth Report of 1986 in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986, in its Ninth Report of 1986 in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 and in its Eighteenth Report of 1986 in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1986. It now appears that the practice is being extended to fields other than taxation law, most obviously in the case of the Government's announced proposal to change the television station ownership rules in the Broadcasting Act 1942 but also in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 on which the Committee commented in its First Report of 1987, presented last week.

The practice of `legislation by Press release' is something to which the Committee takes objection on a number of grounds. In the first place it carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the executive rather than in accordance with the laws made by Parliament. The practice treats the passage by the Parliament of the necessary retrospective legislation `ratifying' the announcement as a pure formality. It places the Parliament in the invidious position of either agreeing to the legislation without significant amendment or bearing the odium of overturning the arrangements which many people may have made in reliance on the ministerial announcement.

Secondly, quite apart from the debilitating effect of the practice on the Parliament, it leaves the law in a state of uncertainty. Those such as lawyers and accountants who must attempt to advise their clients on the law are compelled to study ministerial announcements to ascertain what the law is. As the Committee noted in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 in its Ninth Report of 1986, one announcement may be modified by a subsequent announcement. The legislation when introduced may differ in significant details from the terms of the announcement. Finally there is always the possibility, as occurred with Mr Crean's 1974 announcement, that the Government will lose office before it can implement the announcement and that the new Government will not proceed with the proposed change to the law.

The Committee is aware that the Law Council of Australia and various chartered accountants have expressed similar concerns in relation to the increasing practice of `legislation by press release'. The Committee concedes that the making of an announcement of a proposal to change the law with the promise of retrospective legislation to follow may be justified where swift action is necessary to close a loophole which would otherwise lead to a significant loss of revenue. Even then the Committee would suggest that any such announcement should be made to the Parliament so that it may be the subject of debate, and that the period of retrospectivity should be kept to the absolute minimum. However the Committee condemns in the strongest terms the practice of `Legislating by Press release' as a matter of routine. I commend the report to the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many films have been shown by Qantas on its international service in each of the last 3 financial years.
(2) How many of these films were made in Australia.
(3) Is it a fact that for the month of October 1986 no Australian films were shown.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Qantas has screened 72 feature films since November 1982. Four different movies are shown on the various routes at any one time, each for a period of two months, making a total of 24 films shown each year.

(2) Four of these films have been Australian made, namely: Phar Lap (screened for four months), Careful He Might Hear You, Undercover and Coolangatta Gold. However, a further seven Australian made films, including Gallipoli and The Man from Snowy River were shown between 1980-1983.
(3) No Australian films were shown during October 1986.
Qantas has advised that it is Company policy to give preference to Australian films, provided they meet its normal selection criteria with respect to subject matter, quality and passenger acceptance.
In this respect the Company will be screening ``Crocodile Dundee'' and ``Malcolm'' during the first half of this year.

The Company has advised that a major problem with the screening of Australian made movies is that present inflight film screening facilities are not always compatible with the format of Australian movies. To overcome this the company is installing new video equipment throughout the fleet and it is expected that once completed in April this year, the Company will be able to greatly increase the number of Australian films shown on its flights.

In addition, the Company is proposing to hold a ``Selling to the Airlines'' seminar in October this year to acquaint local film makers with the needs of the airline market in general, and Qantas in particular. The Company has noted a marked unwillingness on the part of Australian producers to accept airline bookings and it is hoped that the forthcoming seminar will help overcome most of the problems in this area.
